The Sun has been radiating energy for the past 4.5 billion years or so, sustaining all life on earth, and is expected to continue to do so for another 4.5 billion years! Afterall, a mass of just one kilogram contains energy equal to 9 x 10^16 joules! Based on that, and looking around ourselves and watching all the stars, galaxies and the rest of the observable universe, we would think that the total energy of the universe must be an inconceivably large quantity. But the contrary is true. Yes, scientists think that the total energy of the universe is probably zero. It sounds weird, but light, matter and antimatter belong to a group that physicists call "positive energy", however, there is an equal amount of "negative energy" stored in the gravitational attraction that exists between all the positive-energy particles, precisely balancing each other. Consequently, there is no energy in the universe at all. Stephen Hawking explains the concept of negative energy in his book The Theory of Everything* "Two pieces of matter that are close to each other have less energy than the same two pieces a long way apart, because you have to expend energy to separate them against the gravitational force that is pulling them together," he wrote. * https://arxiv.org/ftp/gr-qc/papers/9910/9910036.pdf Since it takes positive energy to separate the two pieces of matter, gravity must be using negative energy to pull them together. Thus, the gravitational field has negative energy. In the case of a universe that is approximately uniform in space, one can show that this negative gravitational energy exactly cancels out the positive energy represented by matter. So the total energy of the universe is zero. In another essay "A Universe From Nothing"* - American astrophysicists Alexei Filippenko and Jay Pasachoff explain gravity's negative energy by way of an example: "If you drop a ball from rest (defined to be a state of zero energy), it gains energy of motion (kinetic energy) as it falls. But this gain is exactly balanced by a negative gravitational energy as it comes closer to Earth’s center, so the sum of the two energies remains zero." * https://www.astrosociety.org/publications/a-universe-from-nothing/ In other words, the ball's positive energy increases, but at the same time, negative energy is added to the Earth's gravitational field. What was a “zero-energy ball at rest” in space turns into a “zero-energy ball that is falling through space”. Stretching it further, the universe as a whole can be compared to this ball. Initially, that is, before the big bang, the ‘universe-ball’ was at rest. Now, after the big bang, it is falling: light and matter exist, and they are moving. And yet, because of the negative energy built into the gravity field created by these particles, the total energy of the universe remains zero.
